questiontext.text:
Inverting using completion of the square


The function:

\(\qquad F(s)={4s\over s^2+2s+5}\)

does not appear in the table of transforms and, again, needs amending before we can find its inverse transform. In this case, because \(s^2+2s+5\) does not have nice factors, we complete the square in the denominator:

\(\qquad s^2+2s+5\equiv (s+1)^2+4\)

and so

\(\qquad F(s)={4s\over s^2+2s+5}={4s\over (s+1)^2+4}\)

Now the numerator needs amending slightly to enable us to use the appropriate rule in the table of transforms (Table 1, Rule 8):

\[\begin{aligned} F(s)={4s\over (s+1)^2+4}&=4\left\{{s+1-1\over (s+1)^2+4}\right\}\\ &=4\left\{{s+1\over (s+1)^2+4}-{1\over (s+1)^2+4}\right\}\\ &={4(s+1)\over (s+1)^2+4}-2\left[{2\over (s+1)^2+4}\right] \end{aligned}\]

Hence

\[\begin{aligned} {\cal L}^{-1}\{F(s)\}&=4{\cal L}^{-1}\left\{{s+1\over (s+1)^2+4}\right\}-2{\cal L}^{-1}\left\{{2\over (s+1)^2+4}\right\}\\ &=4\text{e}^{-t}\cos 2t\,.\,u(t)-2\text{e}^{-t}\sin 2t\,.\, u(t)\\ &=\text{e}^{-t}[4\cos 2t-2\sin 2t]u(t)\end{aligned}\]
